title: Is the Ranger shuttle from Interstellar any realistic or possible? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Ranger is an amazing bit of tech: Single Stage to Orbit (1)multiple timeswithout refuelingtank-like durability (for a spacecraft anyway)Aeronautic flight without actual wings, but withelectrically-powered air turbine instead of fuel-burning jets (especially handy when you don’t know what kind of atmosphere you’ll be in)attitude mostly controlled by reaction control thrustersWater-landing capable (2)Water takeoff capable (3)Seats four in roomy comfort (4)…along with a mission-dedicated robotIn a package less than 20 m long, less than 4m tall, less than 8 m wide (estimates)The Ranger is insanely energy-hungry; good thing it has two (!) Tokamak-style fusion reactors for generating electricity. So the Interstellar Wiki says, anyway… So, to answer your question, in a word, No. There is nothing even remotely realistic about the Ranger shuttle, and the technologies it demonstrates are not even foreseeable by the ~2060’s as suggested by the script. Has been done, but only from lunar surface to lunar orbit, and then only one-wayExisting technologyProbably could be done with today’s technology, but nobody wants toTechnology exists but has not yet been employed
